content.raw: Was there a design document for this? Or did you design this with Steffi? Just curious.
content.html: Was there a design document for this? Or did you design this with Steffi? Just curious.

content.raw: designed this with @spaepcke. We found the need for these tools after a user study for the model editor so we went ahead and added these two features. We can update the model editor design document to reflect this.
content.html: designed this with @spaepcke. We found the need for these tools after a user study for the model editor so we went ahead and added these two features. We can update the model editor design document to reflect this.

content.raw: It would be nice to update the design document with some of your design decisions, but I'll start reviewing it now anyway.
content.html: It would be nice to update the design document with some of your design decisions, but I'll start reviewing it now anyway.

content.raw: sure will do that, thanks
content.html: sure will do that, thanks

content.raw:
When I align multiple models, it uses the last item that I select as the base, as you say in the description of this pull request. This feels backwards to me. I would expect the first thing I select to be the base. It could go either way, but it isn't clear which is actually the base. Should there be a different highlighting color for the one that will be used as the base for alignment?

Or maybe show a ghost image of what the alignment would look like as the mouse cursor hovers over each alignment option?
content.html:
When I align multiple models, it uses the last item that I select as the base, as you say in the description of this pull request. This feels backwards to me. I would expect the first thing I select to be the base. It could go either way, but it isn't clear which is actually the base. Should there be a different highlighting color for the one that will be used as the base for alignment?

Or maybe show a ghost image of what the alignment would look like as the mouse cursor hovers over each alignment option?

content.raw:
@spaepcke, thoughts on this?  

this was implemented after looking at 3dsmax studio and maya where the last selected obj is used as the base.
content.html:
@spaepcke, thoughts on this?

this was implemented after looking at 3dsmax studio and maya where the last selected obj is used as the base.

content.raw:
I agree, the first object selected should be the "base".

You could add a drop-down in the align tool that lets you specify what the movement will be relative too. See inkscape for an example.
content.html:
I agree, the first object selected should be the "base".

You could add a drop-down in the align tool that lets you specify what the movement will be relative too. See inkscape for an example.

content.raw:
The alignment says has labels X, Y, and Z, but there's no indication for what those directions mean in the 3D rendered gazebo scene. I have to just click one to see which direction it is.

As a developer, I know that I can hold x, y, or z while panning to move the camera along those axes, but without that knowledge, it's not immediately discoverable.
content.html:
The alignment says has labels X, Y, and Z, but there's no indication for what those directions mean in the 3D rendered gazebo scene. I have to just click one to see which direction it is.

As a developer, I know that I can hold x, y, or z while panning to move the camera along those axes, but without that knowledge, it's not immediately discoverable.

content.raw: I noticed that the alignment tool doesn't take into account re-scaled objects. For example, place two boxes, then resize one of them to be bigger in every dimension. Then if you hover over the alignment options, there will be no difference between the three alignment options for each axis.
content.html: I noticed that the alignment tool doesn't take into account re-scaled objects. For example, place two boxes, then resize one of them to be bigger in every dimension. Then if you hover over the alignment options, there will be no difference between the three alignment options for each axis.

content.html: fixed, 61dcee7
